content: I've been feeling really overwhelmed with everything at work and home. I don't know how to handle it all.
I'm hearing that you're feeling overwhelmed right now. That sounds really difficult. Can you tell me what 'overwhelmed' feels like in your body?
It's like this heavy weight on my chest, and my mind is constantly racing with all the things I need to do.
Thank you for sharing that. A heavy weight on your chest and a racing mind - that sounds exhausting. When you notice that racing mind, what kinds of thoughts are going through it?
It's like a never-ending list. Work deadlines, taking care of my kids, the house is a mess, I need to call my mom back... it just goes on and on.

So there's this continuous stream of tasks and responsibilities. That makes complete sense why you'd feel overwhelmed. What happens if you just pause for a moment and notice that you're having these thoughts, rather than getting caught up in the content of them?
I've been struggling with anxiety around public speaking. I have a big presentation coming up and I'm terrified.

It sounds like this upcoming presentation is bringing up a lot of fear for you. That's completely understandable - public speaking can feel really vulnerable. What are you noticing about this terror? How does it show up for you?
My heart starts racing just thinking about it. I imagine everyone judging me, thinking I don't know what I'm talking about.

So there's the physical sensation of your heart racing, and then these anticipatory thoughts about being judged. When you're in those imagined scenarios where people are judging you, what do you believe that would mean about you?
That I'm not good enough, that I'm a fraud and everyone will finally see that I don't belong here.

That's such a painful story to carry - this sense of being a fraud and not belonging. It makes perfect sense that your nervous system would be so activated around the presentation. Can you feel how much younger, more vulnerable part of you is behind those fears?
Yeah, it does feel like a young part of me that's scared of being exposed and rejected.
What does that young part of you need right now? Not to fix or change anything, just to be seen and understood?
I'm going through a difficult divorce and I'm struggling with feelings of failure and shame.
Divorce can bring up such intense and complex emotions. I'm hearing failure and shame particularly. Can you help me understand what those feelings are like for you right now?
I feel like I failed at something so fundamental - like I couldn't even make my marriage work. And I'm ashamed because I feel like everyone is judging me.

There's something so tender about how you're holding this - feeling like you failed at something fundamental. When you say you 'couldn't make your marriage work,' what does that assume about your role in the relationship?
I guess it assumes that it was my job to make it work, that I should have been able to fix whatever was wrong.

Ah, so there's this belief that you were responsible for making the marriage work on your own. That's such a heavy burden to carry. What would it be like to consider that a marriage involves two people, and perhaps there were dynamics that went beyond what any one person could control?
That's hard to accept. It's easier somehow to blame myself than to face the complexity of what really happened.
That's such important awareness - noticing how self-blame can sometimes feel safer than facing the full complexity of a situation. What makes accepting that complexity feel so difficult right now?
I keep starting projects and never finishing them. I feel like I'm always procrastinating and I hate myself for it.

I can hear the frustration and self-criticism in what you're sharing. This pattern of starting things and not finishing them seems to be really troubling for you. What's it like when you notice yourself procrastinating?
It's like I know I should be working on something, but I just can't make myself do it. Then I end up scrolling social media or cleaning my house instead.

So there's this 'should' energy around working on things, and then something happens where you find yourself doing other activities instead. What do you notice happens in your body or emotions when you think 'I should be working on this'?
I get this tight feeling in my stomach, and I start feeling anxious and overwhelmed. Then I want to escape from those feelings.

That makes so much sense - when we feel tight and anxious, of course our system wants to find relief. It sounds like cleaning or scrolling might be ways of soothing those uncomfortable sensations. What if procrastination isn't something wrong with you, but actually a protective strategy your system has developed?
I never thought of it that way. Maybe I'm trying to protect myself from the fear of failing or not being good enough.

That's such a beautiful insight. So procrastination might actually be your system's way of avoiding the risk of not being good enough. What would it be like to approach your projects with curiosity about this protective part, rather than trying to force it to change?
I've been having conflicts with my teenage daughter and I don't know how to connect with her anymore.
Feeling disconnected from your daughter sounds really painful. Teenage years can be such a challenging time for relationships. What's happening between you two that has you feeling this way?
She's become so distant and moody. Everything I say seems to irritate her. We used to be so close, and now it feels like she doesn't want anything to do with me.

It sounds like you're grieving the closeness you used to have. That shift from being close to feeling shut out must be heartbreaking. When you notice yourself getting irritated back at her moodiness, what happens inside you?
I get defensive and hurt. Sometimes I hear myself saying things like 'When I was your age...' or getting critical of her attitude.

So when you feel shut out and hurt, something protective comes up that wants to defend or correct. That makes complete sense - rejection from our children can activate such tender places in us. What do you imagine your daughter experiences when she hears those defensive responses?
Probably that I don't understand her, that I'm just another adult trying to control her. Maybe she feels even more alone.

What a generous and wise perspective. You're recognizing how your hurt and defensive reactions might actually push her further away, even though that's the opposite of what you want. What would it look like to meet her distancing with curiosity instead of defensiveness?
